awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Residential Segregation and Policing Styles
awd_abstract_narration:
Residential Segregation and Policing Styles

This project explores the processes by which different places, and thus people, come to experience fundamentally different styles of policing. It uses the case of a police department's project of redrawing its district boundaries in the context of a highly segregated Rust Belt city.  In contrast to many redistricting efforts that aim to more evenly distribute urban service provision across a jurisdiction, this redistricting intended to concentrate distinct policing problems within the new districts.  In so doing, it created more racially homogenous districts and opened the door for divergence in policing practices.  This study examines the motivations for and consequences of this reform.  It aims to expand our understanding of the varied roles that the police play in projects of social control and service provision by identifying the relational and socially constructed nature of policing priorities across the city. The research has the potential to inform policing and to improve relationships between police and the policed.

The researcher describes the motivations for and consequences of the redistricting through a multi-method design that links the structural context of racial residential segregation to institutional priorities that in turn shape on-the-ground policing. First, the researcher will interview 80 stakeholders involved in or affected by the redistricting in order to identify the networks and interests that structured the redistricting process. Next, the researcher explores the current social organization of police work at the district-level through a year of ethnographic observation of two of the most affected districts. Finally, the researcher describes the intended and unintended consequences of the change through longitudinal analysis of calls for service data, arrest and citation data, crime data, and demographic data. In examining the relationship between residential segregation and policing styles, the researcher identifies the dynamics of policing that not only re-inscribe and maintain segregation boundaries, but reconstitute the nature of segregation by actively creating different kinds of spaces in the city. Thus, this research both contributes to sociology of crime, criminology and community studies but it also contributes to strengthening the relationship between police and the policed. It contributes to understanding how to change the processes that lead to the material and symbolic racial disparities that characterizes these relationships and attends to broader historical and institutional processes as well as mandates at the institutional level.

por.por_cntn:
This project examines the relationships between racial segregation and policing practices through the case of an urban police department’s redistricting process. While many redistricting reforms aim to evenly distribute workload across districts, this redistricting created high-crime districts and low-crime districts, aligning police district boundaries with the city’s stark racial residential segregation boundaries in the process. I investigate how this alignment occurred and with what consequences. I begin by describing the motivations for and process of redistricting through in-depth interviews with 37 decision-makers, including police executives, elected officials, and representatives of business entities and community agencies. I then characterize changes in district-level work environments through analysis of data on calls for service. Finally, I examine how officers in two of the most transformed districts – one majority black and one predominately white – conduct and think about their work via 13 months of ethnographic observation, mostly in the form of ride-alongs. Through this multi-method approach, I show how spatially-organized and institutionally-mediated practices drive racial disproportionality, even as they can bolster officers’ colorblind interpretations of their work.

The redistricting was rooted in the logic of increasingly popular community-based and problem-oriented policing strategies. It encouraged district commanders to develop tailored responses to geographically-distinct issues. In low-crime districts, the police sought to preserve the economic value of the downtown and middle-class neighborhoods by addressing quality of life issues. In high-crime districts, the police prioritized crime control through formal law enforcement tactics like traffic stops and subject stops; officers had fewer resources for service provision, even as they dealt with a higher volume of calls for assistance. These divergent spatial priorities carried racial consequences: compared to white residents, those in predominately black and Latino districts received inconsistent assistance and were subject to disproportionate social control. 

This project contributes to contemporary discussions on race and policing by demonstrating that racial outcomes are rooted in the administrative decisions that align existing structural inequalities, institutional priorities, and the daily pressures that shape police-citizen interactions. While much research on racial inequality and policing focuses on the experiences of residents in disadvantages and heavily police neighborhoods, I take a comparative approach that centers the relational dynamics in high-crime and low-crime neighborhoods and the power of urban decision-makers.
